item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 9
item.description: A member of an insurgent group which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, took guard at a polling booth in Manipur.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A member of Kuki National Front, an insurgent group which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, guarding a polling booth at Natheljang, Manipur.

item.title: Britain’s Power to Disown Its Citizens Raises Questions
item.description: The government’s ability to revoke citizenship, and the fact it has used that ability against people who were later killed in drone strikes, has fueled concern.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Germans Loosen Their Purse Strings
item.description: Fresh statistics on German trade show a sharp increase in imports from the euro zone and the broader European Union.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Iran Nuclear Talks Need ‘Intensive Work,’ Envoys Say
item.description: A joint statement issued at the end of the latest round of talks on the Iranian nuclear dispute suggested that extensive disagreements remain.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sayeda Zeinab Journal: Muslim Shrine Stands as a Crossroads in Syria’s Unrest
item.description: Religious fervor has driven some to protect a once-bustling shrine outside of Damascus, while others see it as a target.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the shrine of Zeinab, a granddaughter of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Lens Blog: Embracing Ambiguity in Israel
item.description: Frederic Brenner looks at his complex identity through the lens of Israel’s ambiguities and contrasts.
item.category: " An Archeology of Fear and Desire"
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:credit: Frederic Brenner courtesy Howard Greenberg Gallery

item.title: Blast at Market in Pakistani Capital Kills at Least 22
item.description: The death toll is expected to rise in the attack, which came while the Taliban, which denied any role in the blast, were in talks with the government.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Pro-Russian Demonstrators in Eastern Ukraine Urged to Stand Down
item.description: A group of protesters who have seized the government headquarters in Donetsk were urged by local politicians to give up and hand over weapons.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Graft Inquiry Fells Another Ally of Former Security Chief
item.description: The expulsion from the Communist Party of Guo Yongxiang for accepting “huge” bribes could help the government in its investigation of Zhou Yongkang, the former head of internal security forces.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: India Ink: Rash of Suicides Underlines Maharashtra Farmers’ Discontent
item.description: The state’s small farmers have reliably voted for the Indian National Congress and its coalition partner, the Nationalist Congress Party, in the past, but the party’s rivals are tapping into the frustration felt by members of this voting bloc.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Chandra Shekhar Mahajan, left, Pramod Bhagwant Mahajan, center, and Renutai Bhagwant Mahajan are the family of Bhagwanta Haribhar Mahajan, a farmer who committed suicide in Dhanora village in the Vidarbha region of Maharashtra, on March 20.

item.title: Russia Plotting for Ukrainian Influence, Not Invasion, Analysts Say
item.description: Moscow’s goals are focused on a long-range strategy of preventing Ukraine from escaping Russia’s economic and military orbit, political analysts said.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: ArtsBeat: Authorities Release German Art Trove
item.description: The release will allow a team of international experts to begin a yearlong examination of the works in the collection of Cornelius Gurlitt.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Israel Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ by Kerry’s Remarks on Peace Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry appeared to lay the blame on Israel for the crisis in the talks, prompting an unusually strong rebuke.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Prosecutor Tries to Rattle Pistorius in Murder Trial
item.description: While cross-examing the athlete Oscar Pistorius, on trial for his girlfriend’s death, the prosecutor displayed a photograph of her bloodied head and all but ordered the defendant to look.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arrived to the court in Pretoria on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing’s Neighbors Resist Transfer of Its Polluting Industries
item.description: Beijing’s latest effort to move energy-intensive, polluting businesses out of the Chinese capital has run into resistance from regional governments who are unenthusiastic about taking more industrial castoffs.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Smoke rises from a steel plant in Tangshan, Hebei Province. Beijing's plan to reduce its own pollution by moving heavy industry to neighboring localities such as Hebei is meeting resistance.

item.title: Early Count in Indonesia Favors Largest Opposition Party
item.description: The biggest prize in Wednesday’s balloting is the House of Representatives, where the results will bear directly on the presidential election in July.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: A man cast his ballot in Banten Province on Wednesday.

item.title: Europe’s Many Jobless See Little Light Yet From Glimmers of a Recovery
item.description: Even as signs of an economic rebound emerge in the euro zone, the human cost of the five-year downturn continues to rise.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Updated Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
item.description: Tracing the mysterious pings, and other points of interest.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Race for a Top Job in Europe Hits the Road
item.description: Jean-Claude Juncker, seeking to be the next president of the European Commission, embarked on an American-style campaign bus tour.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Titus Simoens for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker, left, who is seeking the European Commission presidency, on his campaign bus in Belgium on Tuesday.

item.title: How to Think Like the Dutch in a Post-Sandy World
item.description: Can Henk Ovink sell Americans on a new approach to flooding — letting the water in?
item.dc:creator: By RUSSELL SHORTO
item.media:credit: Olivia Locher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Henk Ovink, a Dutch water-management expert, is trying to persuade Americans to approach water the way the Dutch do.

item.title: Medical Charity Sharply Criticizes U.N. Operation in South Sudan
item.description: Doctors Without Borders issued a statement accusing international peacekeeping officials of ignoring squalid conditions at a refugee camp in the capital.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: British Culture Secretary Quits Amid Uproar Over Expenses
item.description: Maria Miller had apologized in Parliament for having overclaimed expenses, but by speaking for just 32 seconds, she prompted an avalanche of criticism.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Kim Further Consolidates Power as North Korea’s Leader
item.description: Personnel decisions being made at meetings this week should determine who is rising and who is falling in the dictator’s circle of power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Search for Malaysian Jet to Be Costliest in History
item.description: Many of the governments involved will face a difficult decision about whether to keep bearing the extraordinary expense.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: A diver with an Australian Defense Force vessel on Tuesday. The hunt for Flight 370 is costing millions of dollars each day.

item.title: India Ink: Congress Picks Local Legislator to Face Heavyweight Rivals in Varanasi
item.description: Ajay Rai, a member of the state assembly, will run for a parliamentary seat that is also being contested by Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party and Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
